data.text: Contents
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust ............................................ 6
Legionella, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa and Safe Hot Water Policy/ MSEPO-20219 / 1.0
Page  of
Introduction

1.1. Legionella bacteria occur commonly in nature and small numbers are often found in the water system of health care premises. The bacteria do not appear to cause a problem unless they are present in large numbers and are aerolised. Pseudomonas aeruginosa (P. Aeruginosa) are opportunistic pathogens, particularly in patients who are immunologically compromised. There can be an association between the presence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in water from taps and other outlets and infection or colonisation in patients in augmented care units. Many of the risks associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa in water can be mitigated by adhering to good infection prevention and control. As the control methods include providing good hot water to the hospital the risk of scalding and burns from hot water systems is also considered.
1.2. This policy incorporates the latest guidance available and has been tailored to meet the needs of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

1.3. Where premises on the organisation's site are leased to third parties, it will be the responsibility of the third party to implement their own policy, risk assessment and procedures, which should be in-line with this policy.

1.4. The Trust CEO, Board and Infection Prevention and Control Committee have approved the information and guidance within this policy. It is intended to prevent or, where this is not practicable, control the risks associated with Legionella species and Pseudomonas aeruginosa in water. Scalding is also intended to be prevented.
1.5. This policy will be reviewed every 3 years or in the light of new guidance, and has been written in conjunction with the Estates Department and Infection Prevention and Control Department.
Scope

The Trust is committed to ensuring as far as is reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare of our clients, patients, visitors, staff and others who may be affected by the use of the water systems and associated services within its premises.
To achieve this The Trust will implement current guidance outlined in:
Health Technical memorandum 04-01 The Control of Legionella, hygiene, “safe” hot water, cold water and drinking water systems 2016 Parts A, B, C and D;
Health & Safety Executive Approved Code of Practice “Legionnaires' Disease The control of legionella bacteria in water systems L8: 2013;
Health Technical memorandum 00: best Practice guidance for healthcare engineering
Legionella, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa and Safe Hot Water Policy/ MSEPO-20219 / 1.0

data.url: MSEPO-20219 Legionella, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa & Safe Hot Water Policy 1.0.002.png

data.text: The Trust has a statutory duty to prevent or control outbreaks of Legionella and P.aeruginosa in the workplace. An outbreak of either disease could result in prosecution under the Health & Safety at Work etc Act 1974 (H&SWA) and Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations 1999 (COSHH).

The Trust policy will be to arrange for and review on a minimum annual basis, the safe, efficient and effective management, maintenance and operation of the systems to prevent or control outbreaks of Legionella and P.aeruginosa
This policy will be applied and adhered to by all managers, employees within the Trust, tenants and other bodies using Trust premises.

Building/engineering services/consultant engineers and contractors involved in the design, maintenance and repair of the systems and associated services will also need to adhere to this policy and procedure
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities
The Water Safety Group meets on a regular basis to discuss and oversee the Legionella and P.aeruginosa policy and Water Safety Plan.
4.1.1 The group's responsibilities shall also include:
The monitoring and reporting upon the efficacy of all implemented PPM Programmes and all other relevant procedures;
The liaison between all other associated teams, such as the Infection Prevention and Control Committee (particularly in an outbreak situation);
The monitoring and reporting upon the efficacy of all training programmes implemented for associated staff;
Review new projects to ensure they are implemented in line with current guidance;

The team shall be easily mobilised to react and monitor the situation, as advised by Infection Prevention and Control Team, should an incident/outbreak be identified, and to report back to the Chief Executive actions taken.
4.1.2 It is usual that the team should meet at intervals necessary to reflect the workload in-hand, but a 2-monthly interval would be considered to be appropriate.
4.1.3 Membership will include as a minimum, representatives from the authorised persons for Legionella, infection prevention and control, nursing and technical consultants and projects.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust

To enable the Trust to fulfil its obligations, staff need to be aware of the clear lines of communication and roles and responsibilities for all matters relating to the control of Legionella, scalding and Pseudomonas Aeruginosa.
Those who are appointed to carry out the control measures and strategies should be suitably informed, instructed and trained and their suitability assessed.
Although training is an essential element of competence it should also be viewed alongside experience, knowledge and other personal qualities, which are needed to undertake a job safely.

4.2.1 Chief Executive has overall responsibility for all aspects of the quality of water supplies within ALL the Trust properties and shall nominate, in writing, a ‘Designated person' to provide the essential senior management link between professional support and the Trust. Furthermore, the Chief Executive shall ensure that adequate resources are made available to ensure that this policy is fully implemented.

4.2.2 Designated Person (Chief Estates and Facilities Director) via their designated deputies is responsible for exercising the Trust's duty of care with respect to the estates and facilities functions and shall ensure suitable and sufficient arrangements are in place for implementing the policy and associated procedural document. Furthermore, the designated person shall provide the essential senior management link between the Trust and professional support and provide an informed position at Board Level.

4.2.3 Senior Operational Manager (Site operational manager estates and facilities) shall accept management responsibility for Legionella and Pseudomonas aeruginosa control and give assurance of its effectiveness. With the assistance of the Water Hygiene Group will prepare and implement an Operational Policy for Controlling Legionella Pseudomonas aeruginosa and maintaining safe water and surface temperatures. Put in place arrangements for reporting an outbreak or suspected outbreak of Legionella or other water associated infections.
4.2.4 Authorised persons will undertake the following:
Accept key operational responsibility for water quality;
Prepare and implement safe operation procedures for controlling Legionella, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa, water hygiene and scalding issues;
Assess the training needs of staff employed in the control of Legionella, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa, water hygiene and scalding (Competent persons) and provide validation of their capability;

Provide assurance regarding the competence of external contractors used for any aspect of monitoring and/or maintaining the precautions for Legionella control, Pseudomonas Aeruginosa, water hygiene or scalding issues;
Ensure operational programmes carried out are kept up to date and compliant;
Monitor Direct Labour reactive works and those of external contractors for good quality and competent work;
Ensure that records are maintained;
Ensure that the in house or specialised contractors respond in a correct and timely fashion to system and/or equipment faults;
Proactively manage problems highlighted during routine monitoring or highlighted during the Risk Assessment Process to a satisfactory conclusion;
Keep maintenance and monitoring records and make available for
inspection and written records to be kept for 7 years and computer records
also for 7 years.
4.2.5 Authorising Engineer will undertake the following:
Provide professional advice (independent from the Trust);
Provide recommendations for the appointment of the Authorised Persons, monitor performance and provide annual audit.
4.2.6 Water Technician/Competent Persons

Provide skilled operation and/or maintenance of a specialist service. They will be appointed (or authorised if a contractor) by the Authorised person and work under their direction in accordance with operational procedures and policies.
4.2.7 Infection Control Advisors
Advise on and monitoring the infection prevention and control aspects of this policy and procedures for the control of water associated infections.
4.2.8 General Managers/Ward/Departmental Managers

Shall inform the Estates Department in writing as and when wards and departments are subject to a temporary closure (more than 4 four days). This will allow the Estates Department to take the required Legionella precautions with regard to decommissioning, disconnection, flushing regime and reinstatement procedures.

Additionally, during normal occupied activity risk assess water outlet usage on at least a twice weekly basis, to ascertain the number of infrequently used outlets. By written submission list any flushing activity of infrequently used outlets or confirm that no underutilisation of water outlets has occurred. This is to ensure that any flushing regime requirement of infrequently used outlets is proactively managed. Augmented ward areas should be flushed daily for one minute.
When re-opening a ward after closure please refer to Estates for guidance contained in the Water Safety Plan.
4.2.9 Capital Projects
All new projects/works will be considered by the Water Safety Group for approval in relation to adequate consideration of water quality and related maintenance activities.
4.2.10 Employees must be aware that they have a duty of care for complying with this policy and the safety of themselves and others.
Every employee within the Trust must:

Ensure that they take reasonable care for his/her health & safety and that of other employees, patients, clients, visitors and members of the general public who may be affected by his/her actions, and the use of the water systems and associated services;
Not interfere with, or misuse anything provided in the interest of health & safety;
Prior to assisted bathing, ensure that hot water outlets are safe to use;
Report to their line manager any infrequent or underused hot and cold water outlets;
Report any doubt about water quality to their line manager;
Prevent waste, undue consumption or misuse of water supplies. All staff need to be made aware for the need to flush low use water systems and participate in these routines;
Prevent contamination of water supplies by inappropriate use of water appliances;
Staff should use the correct basin/sink for its intended purpose;
Adhere to this policy and procedures.
Legionella
The risk of acquiring healthcare associated Legionella depends on such factors as:
Suitable conditions for multiplication (temperatures between 20-45°C and stagnant water);
A source of nutrient (sludge, scale, rust, organic matter, biofilms);
A means of creating a spray (taps, showers and wet cooling systems);
The presence of more people susceptible to Legionella bacteria (immunocompromised).

5.1.1 Within healthcare premises water systems can generate and spread aerosols containing Legionella and patients, visitors or staff inhaling them may develop symptoms of the disease. These can range from mild discomfort to, in severe cases, death. Although reasonably fit individuals can be affected those who are elderly, sick or immunocompromised are more susceptible.

5.1.2 The incubation time following exposure to an aerosol containing live colonies of Legionella can be as little as three days or as long as twenty-one days in extreme cases. Tests to confirm its presence may take a further five to ten days.

5.1.3 The Trust manages and controls Legionella bacteria in their water distribution systems primarily by thermal control however, due to the complexity of hot and cold water systems and with the uncertainty of maintaining a temperature control regime at all times the use of a supplementary control is utilised at some sites.
Assessment of the risk of legionella
5.2.1 A suitable and sufficient legionella risk assessment will be carried out by a suitably qualified and experienced person(s). The risk assessment will include all risk items such as:
Cold water storage tanks;
Hot water generators;
Hot and cold water distribution systems;
Plus, any other water risk items e.g. ornamental fountains.
5.2.2 Plant room and building schematics will form part of the risk assessments. These will also be updated when there are any changes to water systems.

5.2.3 The risk assessment will produce a list of remedial actions in a prioritised order of RISK, DIFFICULTY and COST that will be actioned by the Appointed Persons (including requests for additional resources as deemed necessary).
5.2.4 Whenever there is reason to doubt the current risk assessment is no longer valid the building will be re-assessed, for example:
Change of building use;
Changes to plant and/or water use;
Changes to water systems;
Availability of new information;
Results of checks show it is no longer effective;
Outbreak of Legionnaires' disease associated with system.
Elimination of the risk of legionella

Where the risk assessment shows there is a reasonably foreseeable risk, the use of the water system, part of the water systems or systems of work that lead to exposure will be avoided so far as is reasonably practicable.
Control of the risk of legionella

Where avoidance is not reasonably practicable, there is a Water Safety Plan for controlling the risk from exposure that will be implemented and properly managed audited annually by the Authorising Engineer.
Pseudomonas Aeruginosa

With respect to  Pseudomonas aeruginosa  this policy is aimed at those wards providing patient care in augmented care units (primarily paediatric, neonatal and adult critical care units, but as case mix and patient susceptibility varies between units a local risk assessment is required to establish if these measures are appropriate in other areas such as renal.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is usually present in biofilms (mixed populations of bacteria adherent to specific surfaces within the water storage, distribution and delivery systems), although they may also be present in low numbers on occasion in the water supplied to the hospital. Biofilms will be present on the plumbing materials in the water system but in most cases Pseudomonas aeruginosa will be concentrated within 2 metres of the point of water delivery at the outlet, i.e. after the water has left the circulation system.

During cleaning, there is a risk of contaminating tap outlets with microorganisms, if the same cloth is used to clean the bowl of the hand basin before the tap. These bacteria may be of patient origin, so it is possible that bacteria, including antibiotic resistant organisms, could seed the outlet, become resident in any biofilm and have the potential to be transmitted to other patients.

To assist with understanding and mitigating risks associated with bacterial contamination of water distribution and supply systems, the Trust will take a risk- management approach to the microbiological safety of water and establish good practices in local water distribution and supply.
The Water Safety plan will identify units with at risk patients where patients are at significant risk from water-borne Pseudomonas aeruginosa contamination associated with the water supply system.
An engineering assessment of the water system, including correct installation, commissioning and maintenance will be undertaken.
The water safety plan will detail operational monitoring of control measures and will include details for the sampling and microbiological testing in identified at risk units.
Investigations into clinical infections will include typing of any strains found to see if there is a possible epidemiological link to the outbreak strain under investigation.
Scalding/Burning risk from hot water and hot water surfaces

To prevent injury from scalding, action in the form of thermostatic mixing devices may be required to limit discharge temperatures. The need for this type of mixer (if any) and recommended output temperature will be in line with current guidance and following a clinical risk assessment.
Whenever patients and visitors have access, the maximum surface temperature of space heating devices and surface mounted pipework within 2 meters of the floor, shall not exceed 43C.
Hot  water  outlets  that  are  not  limited  or  fitted  with  local  thermostatic  mixer valves shall be clearly labelled “VERY HOT WATER” by means of fixed notices.
Training Requirements

All Estates Duty Holders and those competent staff who are chosen to deputise for them will be provided with in-depth training courses so that they are properly updated on new developments in the management and control of water services.

These approved training courses will be undertaken at least every three years to ensure the competent staff can fulfil the performance of their specific duties, or more frequently if legislation or significant system changes arise.

All managers responsible for Trust buildings have a duty of care and must be given training  in  order  that  they  are  aware  of  known  hazards  and  the  safe precautions to adopt to ensure their systems are safe.

In order to ensure a safe system of work the Trust recognises the requirement and importance of involving all disciplines and staff to assist Estates maintain a safe regime of care across the Trust's total estate.
All training will be recorded and controlled by the Authorised Persons.
Monitoring and Audit

data.text: Approval and Implementation

The approval will be undertaken via the three site specific Water Safety Management Groups and implemented by the Operational Management Teams. Ratification of the policy will be agreed by the Joint Document Management Group and uploaded to the Trust Intranet.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 11)
References
Health & Safety at Work Etc. Act
Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations (COSHH) 2002
The Water Supply (Water Quality) Regulations The Water Supply (Water Fittings) Regulations 1999
New installations – Contractors and the on- site staff shall only use materials that are approved by WRAS on the water systems installed in the Trust premises
Any Department of Health Alert Notices
HGN: “Safe” Hot Water and Surface Temperatures
BS7592: 2008 Sampling for Legionella Organisms in Water and Related Materials 014DH ‘Decontamination in Primary Care Dental Facilities' 2012
HCAI Code of Practice 2009
Water Fittings and Materials Directory (WRAS) BS EN806-2: 2005 BS EN806-3: 2006
BS 8580-1:Water quality. Risk assessments for Legionella control. Code of practice
BS 8558:  Guide to The Design, Installation, Testing and Maintenance of Services
Supplying Water for Domestic Use within Buildings and Their Curtilages – Complimentary evidence to BS EN 806.
BS 8554:2015 Code of Practice for the sampling and Monitoring of Hot and Cold Water Services in Buildings.

table_items.text: A change in a service to patients
A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
To have a single policy across the three sites
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To have a single policy across the three sites and offer continuity along with a single way of working
Who benefits from this change and how?
The Operational teams have a single way of working across the multiple sites.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No, the continuity the single policy will bring a positive effect on the way the threes work in relation Water Hygiene.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change? b) If so, with whom?
The Consultation will be held with all Water Safety Management Groups.
